summary: This document is a series of emails from whistleblower Christopher J. Dilorio to SEC officials, appealing a preliminary denial of his whistleblower award application related to Knight Capital. He alleges widespread SEC corruption, obstruction, and failure to investigate money laundering through private equity, hedge funds, and penny stock shells, implicating numerous individuals and entities.

persons.name: Christopher J. Dilorio
persons.context: Author of the emails, appealing the SEC's preliminary denial of his whistleblower award application and alleging extensive SEC corruption and failure to investigate money laundering schemes.

persons.name: Janey
persons.context: SEC recipient of Dilorio's emails, accused of not distributing his information and failing to produce a proper record for his award appeal.

persons.name: Hoecker
persons.context: SEC official referenced as a recipient of Dilorio's complaints and part of the Office of the Whistleblower (OWB), accused of obstruction.

persons.name: Jay
persons.context: SEC official referenced alongside Janey and Hoecker as a recipient of Dilorio's communications.

persons.name: Carl
persons.context: Referenced as having conducted an initial 'investigation' of Dilorio's complaints that is alleged to not have been thorough.

persons.name: Bill Scigliano
persons.context: Identified as Chairman of the Board and a Director at Oleg Firer's Acies Corp, linked to money laundering shells.

persons.name: Oleg Firer
persons.context: Referred to as 'His Eminence' and a 'prolific Bag Man'; his entities like Acies Corp are alleged to be money laundering shells.

persons.name: Barry Honig
persons.context: Linked to Jaclin money laundering shells and mentioned in SEC complaints; associated with entities like GRQ.

persons.name: Justin Keener
persons.context: Referred to as 'Bag Man' associated with JMJ; detailed in Dilorio's 2013 TCR for illegal activity; barred by FINRA in 2013.

persons.name: Jonathan Farkas
persons.context: Referred to as a 'prolific Bag Man' and speculated to be related to Michael Farkas; linked to Trump fundraisers.

persons.name: Michael Farkas
persons.context: CEO of Jaclin money laundering shell New Image Concepts/Blink Charging; largest shareholder in Skyway.

persons.name: Engel
persons.context: Described as a 'Milken/Drexel flunkie' on the Blink Charging (BLNK) Board of Directors.

persons.name: Jonathan New
persons.context: Former CFO of Net Element (NETE) and later CFO at Blink Charging (BLNK).

persons.name: Joshie Sason
persons.context: Linked to Hanover/Magna and various entities (CGFIA, IMDS, NewLead, FreeSeas, PRTH); subject of an SEC complaint regarding bogus notes.

persons.name: Ajay Tandon
persons.context: Co-founder of SeeThroughEquity, LLC, which was subject to an SEC complaint for pump-and-dump schemes involving Net Element (NETE).

persons.name: Amit Tandon
persons.context: Co-founder of SeeThroughEquity, LLC, involved in the same SEC complaint as his brother Ajay.

persons.name: Clayton
persons.context: Referred to as SEC Chair who allegedly never disclosed conflicts related to Sullivan & Cromwell, Jared Fishman, and Knight Capital (NITE).

persons.name: Jared Fishman
persons.context: Described as a Sullivan & Cromwell colleague of Chair Clayton who played a key role in keeping Knight Capital (NITE/VIRT) operational.

persons.name: Berger
persons.context: SEC official with whom Dilorio filed a TCR in 2013.

persons.name: McKessy
persons.context: SEC official (likely from OWB) who, along with Janey and Hoecker, was in possession of Dilorio's 2013 TCR.

connections.description: Dilorio is the whistleblower repeatedly sending complaints and appeals to SEC official Janey, accusing Janey of not distributing his information and failing to produce a proper record.
Dilorio includes Hoecker as a recipient of his emails and appeals, accusing the SEC Office of the Whistleblower of obstruction.
Scigliano was a Director at Oleg Firer's Acies Corp, which is alleged to be a money laundering shell.
Both are mentioned as 'Bag Men' involved in money laundering shells; Keener's JMJ and Honig's GRQ are linked to Jaclin shells.
Engel is on the Board of Directors of Blink Charging (BLNK), where Michael Farkas is CEO; both linked to alleged money laundering shells.
Dilorio speculates they are related, both described as 'Bag Men' involved in financial schemes.
Both are labeled as 'Bag Men' by Dilorio and are involved in similar alleged schemes involving penny stock shells and convertible notes.
Brothers and co-founders of SeeThroughEquity, LLC, which was charged by the SEC for pump-and-dump schemes.
Both are associated with Sullivan & Cromwell; Fishman is alleged to have helped keep Knight Capital (NITE) running, and Clayton is accused of not disclosing this conflict.

events.title: Knight Capital Trading Glitch
events.description: A trading glitch caused Knight Capital Group's stock to collapse from over $10.30 to nearly $2.50; Dilorio suggests it was orchestrated to benefit Blackstone.

events.title: FINRA Bars Justin Keener
events.description: FINRA barred Justin Keener/JMJ as a 'Bad Actor' for failing to provide requested information related to suspicious transactions and convertible notes.

events.title: SEC Jaclin Shell Factory Complaint
events.description: The SEC filed a complaint against Jaclin et al., detailing a 'shell factory' operation involving entities like New Image Concepts (later Blink Charging).

events.title: SEC Charges UBS with AML Violations
events.description: The SEC announced settled charges against UBS Financial Services Inc. for failing to report suspicious transactions, resulting in a $5 million civil penalty.

events.title: SEC Complaint Against SeeThroughEquity
events.description: The SEC brought a complaint against SeeThroughEquity, LLC and the Tandon brothers for pump-and-dump schemes, including promotion of Net Element (NETE).

events.title: Dilorio's Appeal and Allegations
events.description: Dilorio sends emails appealing the SEC's preliminary denial of his whistleblower award, alleging ongoing SEC obstruction and that Knight Capital (NITE/VIRT) is insolvent due to fraudulent activities.

events.title: Dilorio's Formal Appeal Email
events.description: Dilorio forwards a formal appeal for the preliminary denial of his covered action (2015-016) related to Knight Capital, attaching documents and citing news articles about FBI concerns over money laundering in private equity.

locations: 14 Wall Street, New York, NY (Address associated with Acies Corp incorporation)
Washington (Mentioned as a potential site for Mullen EV production, which Dilorio claims is fraudulent)
keyFacts: Christopher J. Dilorio is a whistleblower appealing the SEC's preliminary denial of his award application related to Knight Capital (KCG/NITE), alleging the SEC is corruptly protecting criminals and obstructing investigations.

Dilorio alleges Knight Capital's core business is 'abusive naked shorting publicly traded shells to facilitate money laundering' and that the SEC facilitates this through mechanisms like the Obligation Warehouse (OW).

The document links numerous individuals (e.g., Oleg Firer, Barry Honig, Justin Keener, Joshie Sason, Michael Farkas) to a network of alleged money laundering shells involving entities like Jaclin, New Image Concepts/Blink Charging, and Net Element (NETE).

Dilorio claims the SEC has used his information to bring some complaints (e.g., against Sason, SeeThroughEquity) while covering up larger criminal activities and failing to investigate money laundering risks in private equity and hedge funds as identified by the FBI.
SEC Chair Clayton is accused of not disclosing conflicts of interest related to his former firm Sullivan & Cromwell and attorney Jared Fishman, who allegedly helped keep Knight Capital operational.
